thread.title: Pack of violent beggars GUTTED man at a cashpoint when he refused to hand over any money
thread.title_full: Pack of violent beggars GUTTED man at a cashpoint when he refused to hand over any money

author: ecambridge
title: Pack of violent beggars GUTTED man at a cashpoint when he refused to hand over any money
text:
SHOCK STREET ATTACK Pack of violent beggars GUTTED man at a cashpoint when he refused to hand over any money 
Keith Newbold was heading home from a night out with friends when he was approached by by the men By ELLIE CAMBRIDGE Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments VIOLENT beggars “gutted” a man and left him with “life-changing injuries” in a city centre knife attack – because he wouldn’t give them money. 
Keith Newbold was heading home from a night out with friends when he was approached by beggar Dean Jones and his girlfriend as he went to take money out of a cashpoint at the Haymarket, in Newcastle. North News and Pictures Dean Jones, 26, who has been jailed for 12-and-a-half years at Newcastle Crown Court North News and Pictures 5 Sean Kelly, 23, who has been jailed for 14 months at Newcastle Crown Court for handling attack victim Keith Newbold’s stolen bank card 
Jones asked the 33-year-old for cash and when he refused he immediately became aggressive and demanded a fight. 
A court heard three other men, including Sean Kelly, then came round the corner and joined in the fracas. 
Mr Newbold was knocked to the ground, where he suffered a barrage of kicks and punches and was slashed and stabbed six times as he curled up in a ball to try to defend himself. ncjMedia 5 Blood left on the street after the attack which saw two men jailed 
The attackers then stole his rucksack and bank card and left him for dead, bleeding profusely and drifting in and out of consciousness and in excruciating pain. 
As Mr Newbold, a ground worker, fought for his life, Kelly then tried to use his stolen card to pay for a McDonald’s meal for him and his pals. 
Newcastle Crown Court heard the victim suffered “life-changing injuries”, including three stab wounds to his abdomen, one to his arm and two to his hand. 
Now Jones has been jailed for 12-and-a-half years for wounding with intent while Kelly got 14 months for handling stolen goods. RELATED STORIES DEVIL DAD Father who ‘stabbed his twin month-old sons with knife’ told cops he wanted to 'scare his wife' KNIFEPOINT 'ABDUCTION BID' Teenage girl, 17, 'forced into car at knifepoint after driver pulled in front of her moped' KNIFE HORROR Chilling moment 'teen girl' clutching huge knife lunges towards young woman in vicious street brawl PAEDO'S MURDER PLOT Polygamist accused of sending his wives dressed as NINJAS to kill girl, 14, he sexually abused KNIFED IN THE CHEST Teen who stabbed rapper to death with 'Rambo-style knife' at party cleared after claiming self-defence ‘I DROPPED TO MY KNEES AND CRIED’ Dad-of-two, 28, accused of raping ex-girlfriend at knifepoint breaks down in dock after being cleared 
Mr Newbold said in a victim statement: “What terrified me the most was knowing I had been stabbed but not knowing the impact of it initially. 
“I just wanted to get to safety, I felt my life was in danger. 
“I knew I was bleeding and drifting in and out of consciousness and this made me feel really scared as I had no control over what was happening. 
“It’s despicable they had knives and disgraceful myself and other members of the public do not feel safe to walk through the streets of our own home city. 
“Afterwards I was screaming and crying and was upset and angry I had to be in hospital. No-one has the right to make me feel the pain I had to endure. 
“I now have scars which will always be a reminder of this horrific assault. 
“The attack keeps flashing back in my mind. This is really unfair what I have had to suffer and I still have a long way to go to recover. 
“This was unprovoked and the result has changed my life massively.” 
Mr Newbold had been out in the city centre drinking with friends on August 21 last year. 
Around midnight he walked up Northumberland Street, intending to take some money out to go to catch a taxi at the Haymarket. ncjMedia 5 Following the attack outside the bank blood was left spattered on the floor where Mr Newbold was “gutted” 
Angus Taylor, prosecuting, said: “In the vicinity of the cashpoint he was approached by two beggars, Jones and a female. 
“Jones asked the injured party for some money, the injured party declined and Jones became aggressive and demanded a fight. 
“At this point the other men appeared, one of whom was Kelly. 
“Threatening words were said to have been exchanged before the attack took place. 
“The complainant describes the attack as a blur. He recalls being punched by one man to his left eye socket which caused him pain and he fell to his knees. 
“He felt a knife slash his arm and felt multiple stabs to his abdomen. 
“He was curled in a ball in a defensive position to try to protect himself and there was a barrage of punches and kicks to his whole body during the sustained attack. 
“He could feel pain at the time of the attack and what he feared most was the impact these blows could have on his internal organs.” ncjMedia Newcastle Crown Court heard the victim suffered “life-changing injuries”, including three stab wounds to his abdomen 
The attackers eventually dispersed, stealing Mr Newbold’s bag and bank card. 
Mr Taylor said: “Fearing for his safety he sought refuge in a nearby takeaway. 
“He was drifting in and out of consciousness and bleeding profusely.” 
An ambulance was called and Mr Newbold was taken to hospital, where he was found to have a stab wound to his upper abdomen, two to his lower abdomen, two to his right hand and one to his right arm. 
Mr Taylor said: “The injuries have been life-changing. There is permanent scarring and he is scared to go out at night.” 
Around 25 minutes after the attack, Kelly, along with two other men, went to a nearby Mcdonald’s and tried to use the stolen card to pay for food but it was rejected. 
Jones, 26, of Saltwell Place, Gateshead, admitted wounding with intent and was locked up for 12-and-a-half years while Kelly, 23, of no fixed address, admitted handling stolen goods and got 14 months. 
Recorder Darren Preston said: “He was lucky to have escaped without even more permanent damage than he has, or even death. 
”This was a city centre, where people should feel safe to go about their business.” 
Nick Cartmell, for Jones, said: “He is truly sorry. 
“It was a hot summer’s night, a good night for begging and he and his girlfriend were at the cashpoint and there was an argument. 
“It was a joint attack, he was not the initial stabber and he was not responsible for all of the injuries. 
“The man was gutted in this case but the defendant did not appreciate how serious the injuries they caused were. 
“He reflects back on this as a night of horror at what he has done. It was a horrendous attack on an innocent member of the public using the cashpoint.” 
Scott Smith, for Kelly, said he was taking legal highs at the time and was not involved in the stabbing.
